vulnerability_information:
Hello Hackerone,

**Summary:**
I have found that #38343 is not yet fully fixed, disabled user is not always gets notification about password change when a password is changed via password reset link, then such a notification is not send to the disabled user.

**Description (Include Impact):**
When a password changed in user's profile `When a password changed in user's profile` or `password reset links` for `enabled/active user` receives a notification via email containing that the password was recently changed. This is the fixed that reported in #38343. 

However, it defeats the fix in #38343 because when a password changed in `password reset links` for `disabled/inactive user` does not receive notification via email containing that password was recently changed.

__POC__ 
https://vimeo.com/214135835
password: protection
title: Issue with password change in Disabled Account

activities.message: Glad to hear response from you guys and I appreciate it, are you able to reproduce the steps?
activities.markdown_message: Glad to hear response from you guys and I appreciate it, are you able to reproduce the steps?

activities.message: @clarkowen_ Could you explain the security risk here? Since the user's account is disabled, this wouldn't get you anywhere, right?
activities.markdown_message: @clarkowen_ Could you explain the security risk here? Since the user's account is disabled, this wouldn't get you anywhere, right?

activities.message: A team member pointed out that it's possible to re-enable an account yourself after it has been disabled. So this is indeed a valid issue. I will file a task to get this fixed.
activities.markdown_message: A team member pointed out that it's possible to re-enable an account yourself after it has been disabled. So this is indeed a valid issue. I will file a task to get this fixed.

activities.message: Hi @clarckowen_ I wanted to let you know that we are still looking into this. We'll keep you posted on any progress we make.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @clarckowen_ I wanted to let you know that we are still looking into this. We'll keep you posted on any progress we make.

activities.message:
@clarkowen_ After discussing internally we have deemed the security implications of this report to be non-existent. In order to abuse this you have to have access to a user's email account, and there is a limited time window (the expiration time of the password reset link) in which this could be abused. Therefore I'm closing this as informative. 

Thanks for reporting and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
@clarkowen_ After discussing internally we have deemed the security implications of this report to be non-existent. In order to abuse this you have to have access to a user's email account, and there is a limited time window (the expiration time of the password reset link) in which this could be abused. Therefore I'm closing this as informative.

Thanks for reporting and happy hacking!

activities.message:
It's not necessarily to have an access to a user's email account because if it is, the user's account could have been takeover. It only needs a valid reset link for example left by the victim's computer in an office or computer shops then the victim will never notice that his/her password was changed.

I thought you are accepting best practice reports like this, This is the same issue as #38343 and I wonder why this was marked as wont fix.
activities.markdown_message:
It's not necessarily to have an access to a user's email account because if it is, the user's account could have been takeover. It only needs a valid reset link for example left by the victim's computer in an office or computer shops then the victim will never notice that his/her password was changed.

activities.message:
I think you have misunderstood my report @philip, the security impact here is when a disabled user change a password via password reset link `there will be no notification in user's end.`

When changing password via `https://hackerone.com/settings/pass/edit` then the user will be notified via email. Which is a good practice

When changing password for enabled users/active user via __Password Reset Links__ `https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit` then the user will be notified via email. Which is a good practice.

But when changing password for disabled users/inactive user via __Password Reset Links__ `https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit` the user will not be notified via email. Which is a bad practice. The user should be notified also since you can re-enable an account after it has been disabled.

If an attacker has a valid password reset link then the inactive victim will not be notified that his/her password was changed. Are you really okay with that @philip?
activities.markdown_message:
I think you have misunderstood my report @philip, the security impact here is when a disabled user change a password via password reset link there will be no notification in user's end.

When changing password via https://hackerone.com/settings/pass/edit then the user will be notified via email. Which is a good practice

When changing password for enabled users/active user via Password Reset Links https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit then the user will be notified via email. Which is a good practice.

But when changing password for disabled users/inactive user via Password Reset Links https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit the user will not be notified via email. Which is a bad practice. The user should be notified also since you can re-enable an account after it has been disabled.

If an attacker has a valid password reset link then the inactive victim will not be notified that his/her password was changed. Are you really okay with that @philip?

activities.message: If you really don't have a problem with email notification when changing inactive user's password, please accept my public disclosure so that the others will know and not to report this kind of bug again. Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @clarckowen_ - wanted to follow up on your last comments. This seems to be a regression on our end, but we decided not to implement a fix for the time being and are accepting the risk here. This is a missing best practice, not an immediate security vulnerability. We might get around implementing this again at one point. Happy to publicly disclose this!

> It only needs a valid reset link for example left by the victim's computer in an office or computer shops then the victim will never notice that his/her password was changed.

This is not a feasible attack scenario. [Immutable Law of Security #3](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc722487.aspx#EIAA): If a bad guy has unrestricted physical access to your computer, it's not your computer anymore.

Thanks for your contribution and bringing this to our attention, but, again, we're not publishing a fix for this at this moment. Happy hacking!

Jobert

It only needs a valid reset link for example left by the victim's computer in an office or computer shops then the victim will never notice that his/her password was changed.

This is not a feasible attack scenario. Immutable Law of Security #3: If a bad guy has unrestricted physical access to your computer, it's not your computer anymore.

Thanks for your contribution and bringing this to our attention, but, again, we're not publishing a fix for this at this moment. Happy hacking!

Jobert

activities.message:
Hello sir @jobert, I apologize if you felt regression in your end.

I believe this is unfair, the report #38343 was fixed and my report is almost the same, mine only differs because the issue lies in the __password reset link__ of the Disabled Account, but in my count is this is also a __Password Reset Link__ which is the importance of sending notification when it is used where in the report #38343 mentioned.

activities.message: Hi @clarckowen_ - when we close a report as informative it means that we simply didn't prioritize a fix for it. You're not wrong, we're simply accepting the risk. We will follow up with you in case we ever decide to fix this particular problem. Good luck and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @clarckowen_ - when we close a report as informative it means that we simply didn't prioritize a fix for it. You're not wrong, we're simply accepting the risk. We will follow up with you in case we ever decide to fix this particular problem. Good luck and happy hacking!

vulnerability_information_html:
Hello Hackerone,

Summary:
I have found that #38343 is not yet fully fixed, disabled user is not always gets notification about password change when a password is changed via password reset link, then such a notification is not send to the disabled user.

Description (Include Impact):
When a password changed in user's profile When a password changed in user's profile or password reset links for enabled/active user receives a notification via email containing that the password was recently changed. This is the fixed that reported in #38343.

However, it defeats the fix in #38343 because when a password changed in password reset links for disabled/inactive user does not receive notification via email containing that password was recently changed.

POC
https://vimeo.com/214135835
